item.title: Bulgaria, Unready, Is Poor Host to Syrians
item.description: Even though the number of Syrian refugees reaching Bulgaria is far lower than in other countries, the poorest member of the European Union is still struggling to provide even rudimentary shelter.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: Midsize Cities in Poland Develop as Service Hubs for Outsourcing Industry
item.description: Poland has become a hub for an international corporate clientele that values the countryâ€™s well-educated and often multilingual work force.
item.category: Bank of New York Mellon Corporation|BK|NYSE
item.dc:creator: By JACK EWING
item.media:description: Lodz, Poland, is a former center for textile manufacturing with about 740,000 residents.

item.title: Buying Overseas Clothing, U.S. Flouts Its Own Advice
item.description: In some countries, suppliers to the American government show a pattern of unsafe or abusive conditions.
item.dc:creator: By IAN URBINA

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: U.S. Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker on China Trade Talks
item.description: Following annual trade and commerce talks with China, a senior Obama administration official discusses hopes for economic reforms announced in a Communist Party conference last month and progress on a government procurement deal and protection of trade secret and patents.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexander F. Yuan
item.media:description: U.S. Trade Representative Michael Froman, left, and U.S. Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker shake hands with Vice Prime Minister Wang Yang and Agricultural Minister Han Changfu at the 24th China-U.S. Joint Commission on Commerce and Trade in Beijing.

item.title: Al Qaeda Branch in Yemen Regrets Hospital Attack
item.description: In a rare public apology, the groupâ€™s leader has said that one of his fighters disobeyed orders and attacked a hospital during a December assault that killed 52 people.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Pilot Is Found to Have Crashed Plane in Namibia Intentionally
item.description: Preliminary investigations into a November plane crash that killed all 33 people aboard showed that the pilot intentionally brought the Mozambique Airlines plane down, an aviation official said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: A Snowier Silicon Valley in BlackBerryâ€™s Backyard
item.description: The Waterloo area in Ontario remains a magnet for the high-tech industry, despite the misfortunes of its best-known success story.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former tannery now houses tech companies in Kitchener, twin city to Waterloo, Ontario.

item.title: Q. and A. With Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky
item.description: A group of Russian-speaking journalists on Sunday interviewed Mr. Khodorkovsky, newly freed after a decade of being a political prisoner.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Northampton Journal: Partying Until Drunk and Disorderly in Britain
item.description: British officials consider solutions as large numbers of British youths go out on the weekends to get thoroughly, blindingly and often violently drunk.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers broke up a drunken fight in Northampton. One officer said binge drinking was a problem with British culture.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Targets Lavish Funerals in Crackdown on Official Corruption
item.description: As part of efforts to curb official extravagance, the Communist Party has called for curbs on expensive funeral rites for dead officials and their relatives.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A limousine carrying the coffin of a Jiangsu Province village chief in March. The Communist Party has directed members not to hold lavish funerals as part of a larger campaign against corruption and extravagance.

item.title: Americans Evacuated From South Sudan
item.description: U.S. citizens were evacuated by helicopter from the United Nations compound in Bor, in South Sudanâ€™s restive Jonglei State.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ISMAâ€™IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Dozens Are Killed in Syrian Violence, Even Amid Preparations for Peace Talks
item.description: At least 25 people were killed in Aleppo, antigovernment activists reported, while a suicide car bombing killed at least 10 people in the central province of Homs.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Free to Speak About Russia, but Now From a Safe Distance
item.description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, a former billionaire and a critic of President Vladimir V. Putinâ€™s who was imprisoned for a decade, said in Berlin that he would work to help other political prisoners.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky at the museum at Checkpoint Charlie in Berlin on Sunday before his first news conference since his release.

item.title: Passengers on Bus Near Tel Aviv Flee Just Before a Bomb Explodes
item.description: Alert passengers and a bus driver are credited with saving the lives of those aboard the bus.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: China Deal Gives Apple Big Market to Court
item.description: The agreement could, at least initially, give Apple a big lift into the vast Chinese market, analysts say, increasing its global sales.
item.dc:creator: By ERIC PFANNER and BRIAN X. CHEN
item.media:description: A sales assistant at a China Mobile store in Guangzhou, Guangdong Province. The carrier, China's largest, has reached a long-awaited deal with Apple to sell its iPhones.

item.title: Strategy Remains Elusive for Ukraine Opposition
item.description: Protest turnout was again large on Sunday, but the dayâ€™s tenor was one of acknowledgment that the movement was ebbing as opposition leaders struggle to convey their next step.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: A protester waved the Ukraine national flag from the roof top of a building in Independence Square during a pro-European rally in Kiev on Sunday.

item.title: Japanese Team Dominates Competition to Create Generation of Rescue Robots
item.description: A team of Japanese roboticists was among eight selected to move on to compete for a chance at the $2 million prize in an international competition to pave the way for a new generation of rescue robots.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN MARKOFF
item.media:description: The Johnson Space Centerâ€™s Valkyrie robot competes at completing a task, closing a valve, at the Darpa Robotics Challenge.

item.title: The Lede: A Twitter Message About AIDS, Followed by a Firing and an Apology
item.description: A Manhattan public relations executive loses her job after a post on Twitter about AIDS, race and Africa created an online furor.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY SOUTHALL

item.title: Bangladeshi Factory Owners Charged in Fire That Killed 112
item.description: The case that came to symbolize the appalling working conditions in the textile industry is the first in which the authorities have sought to prosecute factory owners in the garment industry.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Delowar Hossain, owner of Tazreen Fashions Ltd. He has said that just three stories of his garment plant were legal.

item.title: Antigovernment Protesters Vow to Block Elections in Thailand
item.description: Demonstrators in Bangkok vowed to disrupt elections scheduled for Feb. 2 in their campaign to rid Thailand of its most influential political family.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters marched through Bangkok on Sunday.

item.title: In Blow to Leadership of â€™11 Revolt, Egypt Activists Are Given 3 Years in Prison
item.description: The three well-known activists, Ahmed Maher, Mohamed Adel and Ahmed Douma, were convicted under a new law seen as part of the military-backed governmentâ€™s effort to curb dissent.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: From left, Ahmed Maher (in hat), Ahmed Douma and Mohamed Adel in a Cairo court on Sunday.

item.title: International Education: Tension Rises at Egyptian Universities
item.description: Clashes between police and students in Egypt have intensified in recent weeks, partly shutting down some of the countryâ€™s top universities.
item.dc:creator: By URSULA LINDSEY | THE CHRONICLE OF HIGHER EDUCATION
item.media:credit: Hazem Abd Elhamed/Almasry Alyoum, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Egyptian students holding a demonstration in Tahrir Square in Cairo this month. The ouster of President Mohamed Morsi in July triggered student protests against the military-backed government.

item.title: Libyan Army Base Is Hit by a Deadly Suicide Bomb Attack
item.description: At least six people were killed in the blast in Barsis, about 30 miles outside Benghazi.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Michiaki Takahashi, 85, Who Tamed Chickenpox, Dies
item.description: Dr. Takahashi, a researcher of measles and polio viruses, was spurred to action when his 3-year-old son fell ill.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: Attack on U.S. Aircraft Foils Evacuation in South Sudan
item.description: Four service members were wounded on Saturday after aircraft flying into South Sudan to evacuate American citizens were attacked and forced to turn back, officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
